title: Danske lægemiddelstandarder 1997
documentHtml:
Den fulde tekst

Danske lægemiddelstandarder 1997

Efter indstilling fra Farmakopenævnet fastsætter styrelsen herved, at nærværende udgave af Danske Lægemiddelstandarder (DLS) kraft den 1. januar 1997 jfr. Lægemiddellovens §§ 4 og 8.

Meddelelse om ikrafttræden indføres i Statstidende, jfr. Kongelig anordning nr. 742 af 13. november 1987.

Fra samme dato ophæves de af Sundhedsstyrelsen i Danske Lægemiddelstandarder 1996 bekendtgjorte bestemmelser. 

  

  Sundhedsstyrelsen, den 25. november 1996  

 Mogens Bjørnbak-Hansen                      Per Frandsen

FORORD

Med Danske lægemiddelstandarder 1997 (DLS 97) indføres der 4 ændringer, der har fået væsentlige konsekvenser for bogens indhold, i forhold til de tidligere udgaver af Danske Lægemiddelstandarder. Den første er implementeringen af den Europæiske Farmakopes 3. udgave (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed.), der sættes i kraft 1. januar 1997. Hermed tages der afsked med den Europæiske Farmakopes 2. udgave (Ph. Eur. 2nd Ed.), hvor der i alt nåede at udkomme 19 hæfter (fasciculer). Da der ved indførelsen af Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed. er sket en række ændringer, må disse naturligvis få konsekvenser for DLS 97. I de publicerede monografier i Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., er titlen på de enkelte monografier skiftet til engelsk. Dette betyder, at referencerne til monografier i DLS 97 også er ændret til engelsk. Hermed er betegnelser på latin, der har været farmaciens sprog i århundreder, med få undtagelser forsvundet fra DLS. En anden væsentlig ændring er, at den Europæiske Farmakopekommision har vedtaget de såkaldte Standard Terms , som er en omfattende liste over tilladte betegnelser som må bruges i forbindelse med lægemiddelformer, administrationsveje beholdere, lukker m.v. Disse betegnelser bliver obligatoriske i hele EU. I skrivende stund har den formelle vedtagelse af Standard Terms af EU-kommissionen dog ikke fundet sted, hvorfor den endelige ikraftsættelse af disse betegnelser i EU sammenhæng vil blive bekendtgjort senere. I Danmark er de dog blevet inkluderet i DLS 97. Dette har medført en gennemgribende ændring af afsnittet vedrørende lægemiddelformer og især navne på disse. Afsnittet vedrørende medicinske utensilier er fjernet fra DLS. Denne har ellers i en årrække udgjort DLS sektion 4, men da medicinske utensilier ikke er lægemidler, og da Ph. Eur. monografierne derfor ikke har gyldighed, har man vurderet, at disse ikke længere skal bekendtgøres i DLS.

I 1997-udgaven af Danske Lægemiddelstandarder bekendtgøres standarder, der især henviser til den Europæiske Farmakopes 3. udgave (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed.), samt et fåtal nationale standarder, hvoraf de fleste også er gældende i de øvrige nordiske lande. I forhold til Ph. Eur. 2nd Ed. indeholder 3rd Ed. ialt 106 nye og 161 reviderede standarder for råvarer, lægemidler eller lægemiddelformer. Den 1. januar 1997 træder yderligere 1 hasterevideret råvarestandard i kraft.

Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed indeholder 3 nye og 9 reviderede tekster til bogens generelle kapitler. I DLS 97 er der henvisninger til nogle af disse tekster.

I Sektion 1 er »Fortegnelse over love, bekendtgørelser m.m.« blevet opdateret. Fortegnelsens indhold vedrører især lægemidlers kvalitet.

I Sektion 2 er listen med »Fortegnelse over standarder for råvarer« ændret således, at engelske navne har erstattet latinske, ligesom henvisningerne nu er til Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed. For drogerne er de latinske navne dog fortsat anført som synonymer, som en service for brugerne. I øvrigt er 86 nye råvarestandarder og 113 standarder er revideret. Af disse er der en enkelt hasterevision Sulfasalazin . 1 råvarestandard Cinchocainhydrochlorid , hidtil publiceret i DLS, erstattes af en standard i Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed. En standard for råvaren Sterilt vand er udskilt fra Vand til injektionsvæsker . Her er tale om en præcisering af kravene til sterilt vand, da monografien for de 2 råvarer i Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed. er en samlemonografi for begge råvarer. Samtlige råvaremonografier i DLS 97 er blevet opdateret til stilen for opbygning af monografier i Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., også med henvisninger til de heri publicerede metoder.

I Sektion 3 er der foretaget en fuldstændig ændring af afsnittet »Standarder for lægemiddelformer«. De officielle danske oversættelser af Standard terms er sat ind i en fortegnelse sammen med de tilsvarende engelske betegnelser. På denne måde kan man med et simpelt opslag oversætte de nye betegnelser til dansk. Da der er indført en lang række betegnelser, som ikke før var defineret, er dette afsnit øget væsentligt med definitioner, eventuelt suppleret med krav.

Alle ændringerne, der i store træk er omtalt ovenfor, samt en række af detaljerne findes som sædvanlig kommenteret i fagpressen, hvortil der henvises.

Lægemiddelformer

Se forord samt sektion 3 vedrørende Standard Terms

Ændret titel

Alle titler er ændret fra latin til engelsk. 

  

  FORKORTELSER, SYMBOLER OG DEFINITIONER  

                             Forkortelser  

 DLS 97                      Danske Lægemiddelstandarder 1997  

 ICRS                        International Chemical Reference  

                             Substance  

 NLN                         Nordisk Lægemiddelnævn  

 NRP                         Nordic Reference Preparation  

 Ph. Eur.                    European Pharmacopoeia  

 Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed.            European Pharmacopoeia, Third Edition  

 Symboler  

 *                           Angiver en lægemiddelformstandard, der  

                             er baseret på en monografi i den  

                             Europæiske Farmakope  

                  Angiver termer, der kan anvendes som  

                             lægemiddelformbetegnelse ved mærkning.

Ved forkortelser af enheder i det internationale enhedssystem er anvendt de internationalt vedtagne symboler, som fremgår af Handelsministeriets og Industriministeriets bekendtgørelser om det internationale enhedssystem (SI).

Definitioner

Lægemiddelstof

Ved et lægemiddelstof forstås en råvare, der betinger et lægemiddels virkning.

Hjælpestof

Ved et hjælpestof forstås en råvare, der anvendes ved fremstilling af lægemidler, og som ikke er et lægemiddelstof.

Specifikation

Ved en specifikation forstås en af råvare- eller lægemiddelfremstilleren opstillet forskrift, der definerer kvaliteten af råvaren eller lægemidlet. Specifikationen skal omfatte de nødvendige angivelser af råvarens eller lægemidlets oprindelse, sammensætning og fremstillingsmåde, de prøver med tilhørende grænser som skal kunne opfyldes, og opbevaringsforhold der skal respekteres. Specifikationen danner grundlag for Sundhedsstyrelsens godkendelse i forbindelse med optagelse i specialitetsregisteret i medfør af lov om lægemidler.

Standard

Ved en standard forstås en af myndighederne publiceret forskrift, der definerer kvaliteten af en råvare, et lægemiddel eller en lægemiddelform.

FORTEGNELSE OVER LOVE, BEKENDTGØRELSER M.M.

Der er i Danske Lægemiddelstandarder henvist til de med mærkede love, bekendtgørelser og lignende. 

  

                             Lægemiddelloven  

 Lovbekendtgørelse nr. 656 af 28. juli 1995 om lægemidler.  

                             Kongelig anordning  

 Anordning nr. 742 af 13. november 1987 om, at standarder for  

    lægemidlers kvalitet og for fremstilling, kontrol og lagerhold af  

    lægemidler ikke indføres i Lovtidende.  

                             Bekendtgørelser

Sundhedsstyrelsens bekendtgørelse nr. 968 af 13. december 1993 om god fremstillings- og distributionspraksis for lægemidler, som ændret ved bekendtgørelse nr. 642 af 24 juli 1995.

ALMENE BESTEMMELSER

Den Europæiske Farmakope

Den Europæiske Farmakope offentliggøres af Europarådet i henhold til konventionen om udarbejdelse af en Europæisk Farmakope. I Danmark anvendes den engelsksprogede udgave som udgives af »The European Department for the Quality of Medicines« under Europarådet i Strassburg.

Den gældende 3. udgave af den Europæiske Farmakope (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed.) udgøres pr. 1. januar 1997 af en bog, der indeholder de almene bestemmelser, afprøvningsmetoder og reagenser m.v., foruden monografier for råvarer, lægemiddelformer, lægemidler og medicinske utensilier.

Reviderede, nye og udgåede monografier vil fremover forefindes i et årligt addendum til bogen.

Fortegnelserne over standarder i DLS sektion 2 og 3 henviser til gældende monografier for råvarer, lægemidler og lægemiddelformer i enten Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed. eller DLS 97.

Almene bestemmelser for DLS-standarder

For de i DLS optagne standarder gælder General Notices, Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 1.2.

Referencesubstanser

Følgende nordiske referencepræparater stilles til disposition af NLN:

Chlormezanon

Alpha-1,6-Glucan

Glycopyrroniumbromid

Metrizoinsyre

Pentazocinlactat

Nordic Reference Preparations (NRP) og International Chemical Reference Substances (ICRS) kan rekvireres fra: WHO Collaborating Centre for Chemical Reference Substances, S-10514 Stockholm, Sverige.

Opbevaringsbestemmelser for råvarer og lægemidler

Råvarer og lægemidler skal opbevares i beholdere, som beskytter indholdet mod kontaminering. Opbevaringsbeholdere må ikke påvirke indholdet på en sådan måde, at råvaren eller lægemidlet ikke fortsat opfylder standarden.

Råvarer og lægemidler skal i øvrigt opbevares under iagttagelse af de opbevaringsbetingelser, der fremgår af standarden.

Farlige kemiske stoffer og produkter

Råvarer, herunder diluenda, triturationer og lignende, der er omfattet af Miljøministeriets bekendtgørelse om klassificering, emballering, mærkning, salg og opbevaring af farlige kemiske stoffer og produkter, skal mærkes og opbevares i overensstemmelse hermed.

Mærkning af råvarer, mellemprodukter og bulkvarer

Beholdere, hvori der opbevares råvarer, mellemprodukter eller bulkvarer, skal mærkes under anvendelse af følgende betegnelser:

En råvare afprøvet efter en standard i en farmakope mærkes med titlen på standarden eller med det danske navn, med tilføjelse af monografisamlingens navn. For en råvare afprøvet efter en standard i den europæiske farmakope, hvor der stilles specielle krav til renhed ved anvendelse til bestemte lægemiddelformer, skal det fremgå af mærkningen, hvilke særlige krav råvaren opfylder, mærkningen anføres kun når prøven er udført. Såfremt råvaren er afprøvet i henhold til Danske Lægemiddelstandarder, betegnes råvaren med standardens titel med tilføjelse af DLS uden angivelse af årstal.

Et mellemprodukt betegnes med titlen på den standard, hvorefter det er fremstillet, med tilføjelse af monografisamlingens navn. Såfremt mellemproduktet ikke findes beskrevet i en standard, skal det betegnes med fuldstændig deklaration.

En bulkvare hvoraf færdigvaren er en farmaceutisk specialitet, betegnes med specialitetens navn og D.sp.nr.

En bulkvare hvoraf færdigvaren er et magistrelt lægemiddel, betegnes med fuldstændig deklaration.

ANALYSEMETODER

TEST FOR Alpha-1,6-GLUCANS

Prepare the reference gel by pouring a warm mixture of 10 ml of phosphateagarose and 2 ml of glucan standard solution (5 ppm) into a Petri dish with an internal diameter of 90 mm. Place the dish in a horizontal position and let the gel solidify at room temperature. Punch a hole of about 3 mm in diameter in the gel using a punching tool. Carefully remove the plug from the well.

Prepare the test gel as described above using the test solution prescribed in the monograph instead of the glucan solution.

Pipette separately into the well of the reference gel and the test gel 5 microl of anti-alpha-1,6-glucan serum from rabbits or sheep which is commercially available or may be prepared as described in Int. Arch. Allergy Appl. Immun. 42 (1972) 887. Incubate the gels at 4 graderC for at least 48 hours.

A distinct zone of precipitate with a diameter of 7.5 to 10.5 mm is formed in the reference gel. No zone of precipitate is visible in the test gel.

REAGENTS

Buffer (sodium phosphate) solution pH 8.0 Dissolve 34.70 g of disodium hydrogen phosphate R and 0.55 g of sodium dihydrogen phosphate R in water and dilute to 1000.0 ml.

Phosphate agarose Dissolve 10 g of agarose and 10 g of polyethyleneglycol 6000 R in buffer (sodium phosphate) solution pH 8.0 by warming and dilute to 1000 ml with the same solution. Dispense 10 ml portions of the hot solution into glass test-tubes.

Store protected from light in a refrigerator.

Glucan standard solution (50 ppm) Dissolve 5.0 mg of alfa-1,6-glucan NRP (average molecular weight about 2 million) in 0.9 per cent m/V solution of sodium chloride R and dilute to 100.0 ml.

When stored in a refrigerator the solution remains stable for 14 days.

Glucan standard solution (5 ppm) Dilute 10.0 ml of glucan standard solution (50 ppm) to 100.0 ml with 0.9 per cent m/V solution of sodium chloride R. Prepare immediately before use.

KRAV TIL LÆGEMIDLERS MIKROBIELLE RENHED

Lægemidler skal overholde de nedenfor angivne krav til mikrobiel renhed:

KATEGORI 1:

Lægemidler der skal være sterile i henhold til standarden for den pågældende lægemiddelform og lægemidler hvor det af mærkningen fremgår, at de er sterile.

Skal overholde prøven for »Sterility« i Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed. 2.6.1.

KATEGORI 2:

Lægemidler til topikal anvendelse eller til brug i luftvejene, hvor sterilitet ikke er krævet.

- Lægemidlet må ved prøven »Total viable aerobic count« i Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed. 2.6.12. ikke indeholde mere end 10exp2 aerobe bakterier og svampe pr. g (ml).

- Lægemidlet må ved prøven »Tests for specified microorganisms« i Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed. 2.6.12. ikke indeholde mere end 10exp1 enterobakterier og visse andre gramnegative bakterier pr. g (ml), og der må ikke kunne påvises Pseudomonas aeruginosa eller Staphylococcus aureus i 1 g (ml).

KATEGORI 3:

A. Lægemidler til oral eller rektal anvendelse.

- Lægemidlet må ved prøven »Total viable aerobic count« i Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed. 2.6.12. ikke indeholde mere end 10exp3 aerobe bakterierer og 10exp2 svampe pr. g (ml). Ved prøven »Tests for specified microorganisms« i Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed. 2.6.12. må der ikke kunne påvises Escherichia coli i 1 g (ml).

B. For lægemidler til oral anvendelse, der indeholder råvarer af vegetabilsk eller animalsk oprindelse (hvor antimikrobiel behandling ikke er mulig, og hvor Sundhedsstyrelsen har godkendt en initial kontaminering på mere end 10exp3 mikroorganismer i 1 g (ml)). (Lægemidler der udelukkende består af råvarer af vegetabilsk oprindelse eller blandinger af sådanne råvarer er omfattet af kategori 4.)

- Lægemidlet må ved prøven »Total viable aerobic count« i Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed. 2.6.12. ikke indeholde mere end 10exp4 aerobe bakterier og 10exp2 svampe pr. g (ml).

- Lægemidlet må ved prøven »Tests for specified microorganisms« i Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed. 2.6.13. ikke indeholde mere end 10exp2 enterobakterier og visse andre gramnegative bakterier pr. g (ml) og der må ikke kunne påvises Escherichia coli eller Staphylococcus aureus i 1 g (ml) eller Salmonella i 10 g (ml).

KATEGORI 4

A. Lægemidler der udelukkende består af råvarer af vegetabilsk oprindelse og hvor kogende vand tilsættes før anvendelsen.

- Lægemidlet må ved prøven »Total viable aerobic count« i Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed. 2.6.12. ikke indeholde mere end 10exp7 aerobe bakterier og 10exp5 svampe pr. g (ml).

- Lægemidlet må ved prøven »Tests for specified microorganisms« i Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed. 2.6.13. ikke indeholde mere end 10exp2 Escherichia coli i 1 g (ml), idet der anvendes passende fortyndinger.

B. Andre lægemidler der udelukkende består af råvarer af vegetabilsk oprindelse.

- Lægemidlet må ved prøven »Total viable aerobic count« i Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed. 2.6.12. ikke indeholde mere end 10exp5 aerobe bakterier og 10exp4 svampe pr. g (ml).

- Lægemidlet må ved prøven »Tests for specified microorganisms« i Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed. 2.6.13. ikke indeholde mere end 10exp3 enterobakterier og visse andre gramnegative bakterier pr. g (ml) og der må ikke kunne påvises Escherichia coli i 1 g (ml) eller Salmonella i 10 g (ml).

VALG AF ANALYSEMETODE:

Såfremt der ved udførelse af prøverne skal vælges mellem analysemetoderne membrane filtration , plate count eller serial dilution vælges en af de to førstnævnte, hvor råvarens/produktets egenskaber tillader det. Serial dilution må kun anvendes, hvis råvaren/produktet har specielle egenskaber, der udelukker anvendelsen af en af de to andre metoder.

SEKTION 2

INTRODUKTION TIL FORTEGNELSE OVER STANDARDER FOR RÅVARER

Standarder

En standard for en råvare er i fortegnelsen anført ved en titel og en henvisning til en monografisamling. Såvel titlen som henvisningen er i fortegnelsen anført med halvfed skrifttype.

En standards titel svarer til titlen på en monografi. I DLS 97 er titlen ændret til den engelske titel, i lighed med den Europæiske Farmacopes skift af titler, fra latin til engelsk.

Henvisning til en gældende monografi i den 3. udgave af Ph. Eur. (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed.) vil ikke længere være angivet ved hjælp af monografiens løbenr. og udgivelsesårstal for den gældende version, da disse er udeladt i farmakopeens 3. udgave.

Ved henvisningen DLS 97 forstås henvisning til afsnittet om standarder for råvarer i sektion 2 i denne bog.

Danske navne

For hver standard er fastsat et dansk navn. Almindeligvis er det danske navn en direkte oversættelse af standardens engelske titel. Ved en sådan oversættelse er stammerne i de enkelte ord i titlen så vidt muligt overført uændret, også med hensyn til stavemåde, medens de engelske endelser er bortfaldet eller ændret efter sædvane.

I en del tilfælde kan det danske navn kun delvis eller slet ikke opfattes som en direkte oversættelse af den engelske titel. Dette gælder især droger. De danske drogenavne oversættes med den hidtidige stavemåde, som i vid udstrækning også vil være kendt fra tidligere danske monografisamlinger (eks. Clove - Kryddernellike). Hvis stamplanten for en droge er anført i Dansk Feltflora, skal det danske navn heri anvendes.

Synonymer og navneændringer

For drogemonografierne er de oprindelige latinske titler bibeholdt som synonymer til den engelske titel. For tidligere gældende standarder med titler, der afviger væsentligt fra de gældende standarders, er de tidligere danske navne optaget i fortegnelsen som navneændringer.

Søgeord

I første spalte i fortegnelsen er samtlige standarders engelske titler, fastsatte danske navne samt latinske synonymer for droger og navneændringer opført i alfabetisk orden som søgeord. Det danske navn vil dog ikke optræde i første spalte, hvis standardens engelske titel og det danske navn er identisk eller hvis den eneste forskel er -e.

Der kan sædvanligvis ikke søges alfabetisk under en række tillægsbetegnelser, som f.eks: fortyndet, koncentreret, let, renset, steril, tung, tørret, vandfri, vandsugende. I stedet opsøges det næstfølgende ord. For eksempel skal koncentreret saltsyre søges under saltsyre, koncentreret.

Til titlen på en standard i fortegnelsens første spalte svarer det fastsatte danske navn i anden spalte. Ved at opsøge et fastsat dansk navn eller et synonym i første spalte, findes den tilsvarende standards engelske titel i anden spalte. Tredje spalte indeholder henvisningen til den monografisamling, hvori standarden forekommer.

STANDARDER FOR RÅVARER

AIR, COMPRESSED

Luft, medicinsk

Aer Medicinalis

DEFINITION

Prepared by compressing atmospheric air. It contains not less than 19.0 and not more than 23.0 per cent V/V of oxygen (O2-Mr 32.00), about 78 per cent V/V of nitrogen (N2-Mr 28.01) and up to 1 per cent V/V of other gases, mainly argon (Ar-Mr 39.95). Mean Mr 29.

CHARACTERS

A colourless, odourless gas. The mass of 1 l is 1.29 g (1 bar, 0 graderC). At 20 graderC and a pressure of 1 bar, 1 volume dissolves in about 50 volumes of water.

IDENTIFICATION

A. It complies with the test for Carbon dioxide (see Tests).

B. It complies with the Assay.

C. Nitric acid R is poured over copper turnings. The gas developed is collected in an inverted test tube over water until the test tube is half filled. When the gas to be examined is led into the test tube brownishred fumes are immediately formed.

TESTS

Oil, volatile hydrocarbons Determined by a suitable method (e.g. by the use of Drager-Tube,, type Oil 10/a-P) it contains not more than 0.3 mg/(m3.)

Sulfur dioxide Determined by a suitable method (e.g. by the use of Drager-Tube, type Sulphur Dioxide 1/a) it contains not more than 0.0005 per cent V/V .

Nitrogen dioxide Determined by a suitable method (e.g. by the use of Drager-Tube, type Nitrogen Dioxide 0.5/c) it contains not more than 0.0005 per cent V/V .

Nitrogen oxides Determined by a suitable method (e.g. by the use of Drager-Tube, type Nitrous Fumes 2/a) it contains not more than 0.0025 per cent V/V .

Carbon monoxide Determined by a suitable method (e.g. by the use of Drager-Tube, type Carbon Monoxide 0.001%/a) it contains not more than 0.003 per cent V/V .

Carbon dioxide Determined by a suitable method (e.g. by the use of Drager-Tupe, type Carbon Dioxide 100/a) it contains not more than 0.04 per cent V/V .

Water Compressed air stored in compressed-gas bottles (max. pressure 200 bar): Determined by a suitable method (e.g. by use of a Shaw Mini Hygrometer (Shaw, Rawson Road, Westgate, Bradford, England)) it contains not more than 30 mg/(m3).

Compressed air stored and delivered in low-pressure systems: The content is sufficiently low to ensure that the pressure dew point is not exceeded at any point throughout the system (e.g. not more than 700 mg/(m3) at 7 bar at temperatures above 0 graderC).

ASSAY

Use a gas burette (1 in Figure) of 100 ml capacity having at its upper end a two-way capillary tap (A) connected to two capillaries a and b. Capillary b is connected by suitable means to the capillary of a gas pipette (2 in Figure). The lower end of the gas burette is connected to a reservoir by rubber tubing. The lower tube of the gas burette is graduated in 0.2 ml between 75 and 101 ml, the distance between the graduations being not less than 2 mm.

The gas cylinder is kept at room temperature for not less than 6 hours before performing the analysis. The apparatus must be in temperature equilibrium with the surrounding air.

Fill the gas pipette with the absorption liquid, a 150 g/l solution of pyrogallol-R in 5M potassium hydroxide until it reaches the lower part of the upper bulb. Fill the gas burette and the reservoir with an appropriate volume of the deplacement liquid, either mercury or a 22 g/l solution of sodium chloride R saturated with the gas to be examined. By raising and lowering the reservoir and by opening and closing the tap it is ensured that capillary a is filled with the displacement liquid and capillary b is filled with the absorption liquid. 100 ml (+/-0.2 ml) of the gas to be examined is introduced into the gas burette through capillary a. During the measurement the displacement liquid is kept at the same level in the gas burette and in the reservoir. The gas is displaced into the gas pipette and the absorption liquid is swirled gently. After standing for 5 min. the non-absorbed gas is returned into the burette and its volume measured. The non-absorbed gas is then displaced into the pipette returned into the burette and its volume measured again.This sequence of operations is repeated until the volume of non-absorbed gas remains constant. The non-absorbed volume is between 77.0 ml and 81.0 ml.

Rekommanderet af NLN som nordisk lægemiddelstandard.

ALCOHOL

Alkohol

Alcohol

DEFINITION

Alcohol is a mixture of ethanol and water. It contains 98.0 to 102.0 per cent of the declared content of ethanol (C2H6O).

CHARACTERS

It has the characters described in the monograph Ethanol.

IDENTIFICATION

It complies with identification tests A, C and D prescribed in the monograph Ethanol and with a test for relative density with limits that correspond to 98.0 to 102.0 per cent of the declared content of ethanol.

TESTS

It complies with the tests in the monograph Ethanol.

STORAGE

Store in an airtight container protected from light.

LABELLING

The label on the container states as part of the name of the article its content to the nearest whole number of ethanol in per cent V/V .

ALCOHOL 96 PER CENT Sprit, stærk

Spiritus fortis

DEFINITION

Alcohol 96 per cent is a mixture of ethanol and water. It contains not less than 92.6 per cent m/m (95.1 per cent V/V ) and not more than 95.2 per cent m/m (96.9 per cent V/V ) of ethanol.

CHARACTERS

It has the characters described in the monograph Ethanol.

IDENTIFICATION

It complies with identification tests A, C and D prescribed in the monograph Ethanol and with the following test:

B. Relative density (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.5) 0.804 to 0.811.

TESTS

It complies with the tests prescribed in the monograph Ethanol.

STORAGE

Store in an airtight container, protected from light.

Rekommanderet af NLN som nordisk lægemiddelstandard.

CHLORMEZANONE

Chlormezanon

Chlormezanonum

C11H12ClNO3S Mr 273.7

DEFINITION

Chlormezanone contains not less than 97.0 per cent and not more than the equivalent of 101.0 per cent of 2-(4-chlorophenyl) tetrahydro-3-methyl-4 H 1,3-thiazin-4-one-1,1-dioxide, calculated with reference to the dried substance.

CHARACTERS

A white crystalline powder, practically insoluble in water and in ether, soluble in chloroform, slightly soluble in alcohol.

IDENTIFICATION

A. Melting point (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.14) 111 graderC to 115 graderC.

B. Examine by infrared absorption spectrophotometry (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.24), comparing with the spectrum obtained with chlormezanone NRP.

TESTS

Related substances Examine by thin-layer chromatography (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.27) using silica gel GF254R as the coating substance.

Test solution Dissolve 1.0 g of the substance to be examined in chloroform R and dilute to 10 ml with the same solvent.

Reference solution Dilute 1 ml of the test solution to 100 ml with chloroform R.

Apply separately to the plate 10 microl of each solution. Develop over a path of 15 cm using a mixture of 70 volumes of toluene R and 30 volumes of acetone R. Allow the plate to dry in air and examine in ultraviolet light at 254 nm. Any spot in the chromatogram obtained with the test solution, apart from the principal spot, is not more intense than the spot in the chromatogram obtained with the reference solution (1 per cent).

Heavy metals (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.4.8) 2.0 g complies with limit test C for heavy metals (10 ppm). Prepare the standard using 2 ml of lead standard solution (10 ppm Pb) R.

Loss on drying (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.32) Not more than 0.5 per cent, determined on 0.500 g by drying in vacuo at 70 graderC.

Sulphated ash (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.4.14) Not more than 0.1 per cent, determined on 1.0 g.

ASSAY

Dissolve 0.1000 g in methanol R and dilute to 100.0 ml with the same solvent. Dilute 10.0 ml of this solution to 100.0 ml with methanol R. Dilute 10.0 ml of this solution to 100.0 ml with methanol R. Prepare a standard solution in the same conditions using 0.1000 g of chlormezanone NRP. Measure the absorbance (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.25) of the two solutions at the maximum at 227 nm using methanol R as compensation liquid.

Calculate the content of C11H12ClNO3S from the absorbances measured and the concentrations of the solutions.

Rekommanderet af NLN som nordisk lægemiddelstandard.

COD LIVER OIL

Torskelevertran

Iecoris aselli oleum

DEFINITION

Cod liver oil is the purified fatty oil obtained from the fresh liver of cod and other Gadus species, solid substances being removed by cooling. It contains not less than 200 microg (666 I.U.) of vitamin A per gram and not less than 2 microg (80 I.U.) of vitamin D3 per gram.

CHARACTERS

A clear, yellowish, viscous liquid, almost odourless, practically insoluble in water, slightly soluble in alcohol, miscible with ether and with light petroleum.

IDENTIFICATION

A. In the assay for vitamin A, the test solution shows an absorption maximum (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.25) at 325 nm +/- 2 nm.

B. In the assay for vitamin D3, test solution (a) gives a peak corresponding to the peak of cholecalciferol obtained from the reference solution.

TESTS

Colour Not more intensely coloured than a reference solution prepared in the following manner: To 1.5 ml of red primary solution add 12.5 ml of yellow primary solution and dilute to 50 ml with 1 per cent m/V hydrochloric acid solution (Method II, Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.25).

Relative density (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.5) 0.918 to 0.930.

Acid value (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.5.1) Dissolve 5.0 g in the prescribed mixture of solvents. The acid value is not more than 2.0.

Anisidine value (see Annex) Not more than 20.

Iodine value (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.5.4) 150 to 180.

Peroxide value (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.5.5) Not more than 10.

Saponification value (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.5.6) 180 to 192, determined on 2.0 g.

Unsaponifiable matter (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.5.7) Not more than 1.5 per cent m/m , determined on 10.0 g.

Aldehydes Shake 1.0 ml in a test tube (16 mm x 160 mm) with 10.0 ml of hydrochloric acid R for 30 s. Add 0.1 ml of 50 g/l solution of phloroglucinol R in alcohol R, shake again for 30 s and centrifuge for 2 min (3000 rpm). The clear supernatant is not more intensely coloured than a reference solution prepared in the following manner: To 1.2 ml of red primary solution add 0.2 ml of blue primary solution and 0.3 ml of yellow primary solution and dilute to 10 ml with 10 g/l hydrochloric acid solution (Method I, Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.2).

Stearin 10 ml remains clear after cooling in an ice bath for 5 h.

Mercury Not more than 0.2 ppm, determined by atomic absorption spectrophotometry (Method I, Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.23).

Test solution Digest 1.0 g of the substance to be examined in a mixture of 12.0 ml of nitric acid and 5.0 ml of perchloric acid. Perform the digestion in a borosilicate glass tube about 30 cm high with a volume of about 75 ml. Heat the glass tube in a heater block according to the time/temperature program shown below. Cool and dilute to 25.0 ml with distilled water. 

  

                            Temperature        Ramp*        Time  

 Step                       graderC         hour    min  hour    min  

 ---------------------------------------------------------------------

 5                           138             1       15   1      00  

 6                           150             1       30   1      30  

 7                           160                     45          45  

 8                           180                     15   2      00  

 ---------------------------------------------------------------------

time of temperature rise between each step.

Reference solutions Prepare the reference solutions using mercury standard solution (10 ppm) and diluting with a 2 per cent V/V solution of nitric acid.

The test may be carried out using a device for continuous generation of mercury. The test solution is added to the device at a flow rate of 7 ml/min, sodium borohydride solution is added at a flow rate of 1 ml/min and a 180 g/l solution of hydrochloric acid at a flow rate of 1 ml/min. Pass through the device a stream of nitrogen as carrier gas. Measure the absorbance at 253.7 nm using a mercury hollow-cathode lamp as radiation source and, as atomisation device, a flameless system whereby the mercury can be entrained in the form of cold vapours.

ASSAY

Vitamin A Carry out the operations as rapidly as possible, avoiding exposure to actinic light and air .

Examine by ultraviolet absorption spectrophotometry (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.25).

Test solution To 1.00 g of substance to be examined, add in a round-bottom flask 30 ml of ethanol R and 3 ml of a freshly prepared 50 per cent m/m solution of potassium hydroxide R. Boil under reflux in a stream of nitrogen R for 30 min. Cool rapidly and add 30 ml of water R. Extract with 50 ml of ether R. Repeat extraction twice. Wash the combined ether layers with four quantities, each of 50 ml, of water R, mixing very cautiously during the two first washes to avoid the formation of emulsions. Dry and filter the combined ether layers, and evaporate to dryness under a gentle current of nitrogen R. Dissolve the residue in sufficient 2-propanol R1 to give an expected concentration of vitamin A equivalent to 3 microg to 5 microg per ml.

Determine the absorbances of the resulting solution at the wavelengths 310 nm, 325 nm and 334 nm with a suitable spectrophotometer in 1 cm specially matched cells, using 2-propanol R1 as the blank.

Calculation

Calculate the content af vitamin A, as all-trans retinol, in microg per gram from the expression.

Vitamin D3 Carry out the operations as rapidly as possible, avoiding exposure to actinic light and air .

Examine by liquid chromatography (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.29).

Internal standard solution Dissolve 0.50 mg of ergocalciferol CRS in 100 ml of hexane R for spektrophotometry.

Test solution (a) To 4.00 g of the substance to be examined add in a round-bottom flask 60 ml of ethanol R, 5 ml of sodium ascorbate solution R and 30 ml of a freshly prepared 50 per cent m/m solution of potassium hydroxide R. Reflux in a water bath at 50 graderC for 12 min under constant stirring. Cool and dilute with 30 ml of water R and 10 ml of alcohol R. Extract with 50 ml of pentane R for spectrophotometry. Repeat the extraction twice. Wash the combined pentane layers with two quantities, each of 50 ml, of a solution containing 30 g/l of potassium hydroxide R in alcohol (10 per cent V/V ), and then wash with succesive quantities, each of 50 ml, of water R until the last washing is neutral to phenolphthalein. Dry and filter the combined pentane layers and evaporate to dryness under a gentle current of nitrogen R at a temperature not exceeding 40 graderC. Dissolve the residue in 1.5 ml of the mobile phase prescribed under Purification .

Test solution (b) To 4.00 g of the substance to be examined add 2.0 ml (V 3) of internal standard solution, evaporate the solvent under a gentle current of nitrogen R at a temperature not exceeding 40 graderC, and proceed as described for test solution (a).

Reference solution Dissolve 0.50 mg of ergocalciferol CRS and 0.50 mg of cholecalciferol CRS in 100 ml of hexane R for spectrophotometry.

Purification

The chromatographic procedure may be carried out using:

- a stainless steel column 0.25 m long and 4.6 mm in internal diameter packed with cyanosilyl silica gel for chromatography (10 microm), e.g. R-Sil CN 10 microm Alltech:

- as mobile phase a mixture of 98.4 volumes of hexane R for spectrophotometry and 1.6 volumes of isoamyl alcohol R at a flow rate of 1.1 ml per minute:

- as detector a spectrophotometer set at 265 nm.

Inject 350 microl of the reference solution onto the column. Collect the eluate 1 min before and until 1 min after the retention time of cholecalciferol, into a ground glas stoppered tube containing 1 ml of a 0.1 per cent m/V solution of butylhydroxytoluene R in hexane R for spectrophotometry. Repeat the procedure with test solutions (a) and (b), respectively. Evaporate under a gentle current of nitrogen R the three eluates obtained from the reference solution and test solutions (a) and (b), respectively, to dryness at a temperature not exceeding 40 graderC. Dissolve each of the three residues in 1.5 ml of acetonitrile R for spectrophotometry.

Determination

The chromatographic procedure may be carried out using:

- a stainless steel column 0.15 m long and 4.6 mm in internal diameter packed with octadecylsilyl silica gel for chromatography R (5 microm), e.g. Spherisorb ODS 5 microm:

- a mixture of 0.2 g of phosphoric acid R and 99.8 volumes of a 96 per cent V/V solution of acetonitrile R for spectrophotometry as mobile phase at a flow rate of 1.0 ml per minute:

- spectrophotometer set at 265 nm as detector.

Inject two times onto the column, aliquots not exceeding 200 microl of each of the three solutions obtained under purification .

The test is only valid if the chromatogram obtained with the reference solution shows two peaks corresponding to ergocalciferol and cholecalciferol with a resolution greater than 1.4.

Calculation

Calculate the content of vitamin D3 in microg per gram from the expression:

STORAGE

Store in a airtight and well-filled container, protected from light at 8 graderC to 15 graderC.

REAGENTS

Nitric acid corresponding to the Suprapur quality from Merck.

Perchloric acid corresponding to the Suprapur quality from Merck.

Mercury standard solution (10 ppm) Immediately before use, dilute with a 2 per cent V/V solution of nitric acid to 100 times its volume a solution containing mercuric nitrate R equivalent to 1.708 g Hg(NO3)2,H2O in 1000.0 ml of a 2 per cent V/V solution of nitric acid.

Sodium borohydride solution Dissolve 0.3 g of sodium borohydride in a 5 g/l solution of sodium hydroxide R and dilute to 100.0 ml with the same solvent.

Sodium borohydride Na(BH4) (Mr 37.83)

Hygroscopic, cubic crystals containing at least 97 per cent m/m of Na(BH4). Store protected from moisture.

Hydrochloric acid correponding to the Suprapur quality from Merck.

ANNEX

Anisidine value

The anisidine value is defined as 100 times the optical density measured in a 1 cm cell of a solution containing 1 g of the oil in 100 ml of a mixture of solvent and reagent according to the method described below.

Carry out the operations as rapidly as possible, avoiding exposure to actinic light .

Test solution (a) Dissolve 0.500 g of the substance to be examined in trimethylpentane R and dilute to 25.0 ml with the same solvent.

Test solution (b) To 5.0 ml of test solution (a) add 1.0 ml of a 0.25 per cent m/V solution of p -anisidine in glacial acetic acid R, shake and keep in the dark.

Reference solution To 5.0 ml of trimethylpentane R add 1.0 ml of a 0.25 per cent m/V solution of p -anisidine in glacial acetic acid R, shake and keep in the dark.

Measure the absorbance of test solution (a) at 350 nm using trimethylpentane R as a blank. Measure the absorbance of test solution (b) at 350 nm exactly 10 min after its preparation, using the reference solution as a blank.

Calculate the anisidine value from the expression: 

  

        25 x (1.2  A s -  A b)  

        ----------------------  

                   m  

  A s    =    the absorbance of test solution (b) at 350 nm:  

  A b    =    the absorbance of test solution (a) at 350 nm:  

  m      =    mass of the substance to be examined in test  

              solution (a) in grams.

REAGENTS

p-Anisidine - C7H9NO (Mr 123.16). 4-methoxyaniline. Creamcoloured crystals, sparingly soluble in water, soluble in ethanol. It contains at least 97 per cent m/m of C7H9NO.

Caution: skin irritant, sensitizer.

Store protected from light at 0 graderC to 4 graderC.

On storage, p -anisidine tends to darken as a result of oxidation. A discoloured reagent can be reduced and decolorized in the following way: Dissolve 20 g of p -anisidine in 500 ml of water at 75 graderC. Add 1 g of sodium sulphite R and 10 g of activated charcoal and stir for 5 min. Filter, cool the filtrate to about 0 graderC and allow to stand at this temperature for at least 4 h. Filter off the crystals, wash with a small quantity of water at a temperature of about 0 graderC and dry the crystals in a vacuum desiccator.

ETHANOL

Ethanol

CH3CH2OH

Ethanolum C2H6O

DEFINITION

Ethanol contains not less than 98.8 per cent m/m (99.3 per cent V/V ) and not more than 100.0 per cent m/m (100.0 per cent V/V ) of ethanol (C2H6O).

CHARACTERS

A colourless, clear, mobile and volatile liquid, with a characteristic odour. It burns with a blue, smokeless flame. Miscible with water and with ether.

IDENTIFICATION

A. Distillation range (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.11): 78 graderC to 79.5 graderC.

B. Relative density (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.5): 0.790 to 0.794.

C. Mix 0.1 ml with 1 ml of a 10 g/l solution of potassium permanganate R and 0.2 ml of dilute sulphuric acid R in a 10 ml beaker. Cover the beaker immediately with a filter paper moistened with a recently prepared solution containing 0.1 g of sodium nitroprusside R and 0.5 g of piperazine hydrate R in 5 ml of water R. After a few minutes an intense blue colour appears on the paper and becomes paler after 10 min to 15 min.

D. Dilute 1 ml to 100 ml with water R. To 5 ml of the dilution add 3 ml of dilute sodium hydroxide solution R then slowly add 2 ml of 0.05 M iodine. The odour of iodoform develops and a yellow precipitate forms within 10 min.

TESTS

Appearance It is not more opalescent than water (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.1) and not more intensely coloured than water (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., Method II, 2.2.2). Dilute 1.0 ml to 20 ml with water. After standing for 5 min., the dilution is not more opalescent than water (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.1).

Acidity or alkalinity To 5 ml add 5 ml of carbon dioxide-free water R and 0.1 ml of phenolphthalein solution R. The solution is colourless. Add 0.20 ml of 0.01 M sodium hydroxide R. The solution is red. Add 0.30 ml of 0.01 M hydrochloric acid R. The solution is colourless. Add 0.2 ml of methyl red solution R. The solution is red or orange.

Aldehydes and ketones Heat 125 ml of hydroxylamine hydrochloride solution R2 in a conical flask under a reflux condenser, on a water-bath, for 30 min: cool and if necessary add sufficient 0.05 N sodium hydroxide to restore the green colour. Transfer 50 ml of this solution to a similar conical flask, add 25 ml of the substance to be examined and heat under a reflux condenser, on a water-bath, for 10 min. Cool and titrate with 0.05 M sodium hydroxide until the colour matches that of the remainder of the hydroxylamine hydrochloride solution. Not more than 0.9 ml of 0.05 M sodium hydroxide is required. (100 ppm, calculated as acetaldehyde).

Methanol, higher alcohols and esters Examine by gas chromatography (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.28).

Test solution (a) The substance to be examined.

Test solution (b) Dilute 100 microl of methyl ethyl ketone R to 50.0 ml with the substance to be examined. Dilute 5.0 ml of this solution to 50.0 ml with the substance to be examined.

Reference solution Dilute 100 microl of methyl ethyl ketone R and 250 microl of anhydrous methanol R to 50.0 ml with the substance to be examined. Dilute 5.0 ml of this solution to 50.0 ml with the substance to be examined.

The chromatographic procedure may be carried out using:

- a glass column 1.8 m long and 2 mm in internal diameter packed with ethylbenzene divinylbenzene copolymer (125 microm to 150 microm) R (e.g. Porapak Q).

- nitrogen for chromatography R as the carrier gas, at a flow rate of 30 ml per minute,

- a flame-ionisation detector.

Maintain the temperature of the column at 120 graderC for 16 min, then raise the temperature at a rate of 8 graderC per minute to 240 graderC and maintain at 240 graderC for 16 min. Maintain the temperature of the injection port at 200 graderC and that of the detector at 250 graderC.

Inject 1 microl of test solution (a) and at least three times 1 microl of test solution (b) and of the reference solution, alternating the order of injections. Check that the chromatogram obtained with the test solution (a) does not show a peak at a retention tR the same as that of the peak corresponding to methyl ethyl ketone in the chromatogram obtained with test solution (b). Carry out under the same conditions a blank chromatography before each test.

The areas of the peaks corresponding to methanol in the chromatograms obtained with test solution (b) and the reference solution are to be corrected in relation to the areas of the peaks corresponding to methyl ethyl ketone in the chromatograms obtained with test solution (b) and the reference solution.

Calculate the percentage (V/V) content of methanol using the expression:

  a =  area of the peak corresponding to methanol in the  

       chromatogram obtained with the reference solution,  

  b =  area of the peak corresponding to methanol in  

       the chromatogram obtained with test solution (b).

Maximum content: 0.06 per cent V/V of methanol.

In the chromatogram obtained with test solution (b) recorded for 3.5 times the retention time of the internal standard, the total area of the peaks corresponding to the substance with a retention tR greater than that of ethanol is not greater than the area of the peak corresponding to methyl ethyl ketone (0.02 per cent V/V ).

Benzene and other UV-absorbing compounds Examined between 235 mm and 275 nm, the absorbance (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.25) measured in a 5 cm cell using water as the compensation liquid is not greater than 0.50 at 240 nm, 0.30 in the interval between 250 nm and 260 nm and 0.15 at 270 nm.

If benzene is present, maxima occur at about 249 nm, 254 nm and 261 nm. Draw a perpendicular through the maximum at 254 nm and draw a line between the minima at about 253 nm and 259 nm. The difference between the absorbance at the maximum at about 254 nm and the absorbance at the intercept of the perpendicular with the line joining the minima is not greater than 0.045 (5 ppm benzene).

Chlorides (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.4.4) 4 ml diluted to 15 ml with water complies with the limit test for chlorides (1.5 ppm). Prepare the standard using a mixture of 1 ml of chloride standard solution (5 ppm Cl) R and 14 ml of water.

Heavy metals (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.4.8) 12 ml of a solution prepared by evaporating 50 ml on a water-bath to 5 ml and diluting to 25 ml with water complies with limit test A for heavy metals (0.3 ppm). Prepare the standard using a mixture of 5 ml of lead standard solution (1 ppm Pb) R and 5 ml of water R.

Residue on evaporation Evaporate 100 ml on water-bath and dry in an oven at 100 graderC to 105 graderC. The residue weighs not more than 2 mg (0.002 per cent m/V ).

STORAGE

Store in an airtight container, protected from light.

Rekommanderet af NLN som nordisk lægemiddelstandard.

FRUCTOSE FOR PARENTERAL USE

Fructose til injektion

Fructosum ad usum parenterale

Fructose til parenteralt brug skal foruden de nedennævnte prøver opfylde de angivne kvalitetskrav i monografien for fructose i Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., herunder de anførte prøver.

Pyrogener: Skal holde prøven »Pyrogens«, Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.6.8. Prøveopløsningen, hvis koncentration skal være 50 mg/ml, fremstilles med sterilt vand. Ved afprøvningen injiceres 10 ml prøveopløsning pr. kg legemsvægt.

alpha -1,6-Glucaner: Skal holde prøven, »Test for alpha-1,6-glucans«, DLS, sektion 1. Prøveopløsningen, hvis koncentration skal være 100 mg/ml, fremstilles med isotonisk natriumchloridopløsning.

GLYCOPYRRONIUM BROMIDE

Glopyrroniumbromid 

  

 Glycopyrronii bromidum  

 C19H28BrNO3                                 Mr 398.3

DEFINITION

Glycopyrronium bromide contains not less than 99.0 per cent and not more than the equivalent of 101.0 per cent of (3RS)-3-((RS)-(2-cyclopentyl-2-hydroxy-2-

phenylacetyl)oxy)-1,1-dimethyl-pyrr olidinium bromide, calculated with reference to the dried substance.

CHARACTERS

A white, crystalline powder, freely soluble in water and in alcohol, very slightly soluble in ether.

IDENTIFICATION

A. Melting point (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.14) 193 graderC to 198 graderC.

B. Examine by infrared absorption spectrophometry (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.24) compairing with the spectrum obtained with glycopyrronium bromide NRP.

C. It gives reaction (a) of bromides (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.3.1).

TESTS

Solution S Dissolve 0.5 g in water R and dilute to 25 ml with the same solvent.

Appearance of solution Solution S is clear (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.1) and colourless (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., Method II, 2.2.2).

Acidity or alkalinity To 10 ml of solution S add 0.05 ml of phenolphthalein solution R1. The solution is colourless. Not more than 0.2 ml of 0.01 M sodium hydroxide is required to change the colour of the indicator to pink. Add 0.4 ml of 0.01 M hydrochloric acid and 0.05 ml of methyl red solution R. The solution is red or orange.

Related substances Examine by thin layer chromatography (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.27) using silica gel G R as the coating substance.

Test solution Dissolve 0.25 g of the substance to be examined in alcohol R and dilute to 5 ml with the same solvent.

Reference solution Dilute 0.5 ml of the test solution to 100 ml with alcohol R.

Apply separately to the plate 5 microl of each solution and develop over a path of 15 cm using a mixture of 10 volumes of anhydrous formic acid R, 16 volumes of water and 74 volumes of ethyl acetate R. Dry the plate at 100 graderC to 105 graderC for 15 min. Allow to cool and spray with dilute potassium iodobismuthate solution R until the spots appear. Any spot in the chromatogram obtained with the test solution, apart from the principal spot, is not more intense than the spot in the chromatogram obtained with the reference solution (0.5 per cent)

Loss of drying (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.32) Not more than 0.5 per cent, determined on 1.000 g by drying at 100 graderC to 105 graderC for 3 hours.

Sulphated ash (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.4.14) Not more than 0.1 per cent, determined on 1.0 g.

ASSAY

Dissolve 0.300 g in a mixture of 40 ml of acetic anhydride R and 10 ml of anhydrous acetic acid R. Titrate with 0.1M perchloric acid, determining the end-point potentiometrically (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.20.).

1 ml of 0.1 M perchloric acid is equivalent to 39.83 mg of C19H28BrNO3.

STORAGE

Store in a well-closed container.

Rekommanderet af NLN som nordisk lægemiddelstandard.

METRIZOIC ACID

Metrizoinsyre

Acidum metrizoicum

C12H11I3N2O4 Mr 628

DEFINITION

Metrizoic acid contains not less than 98.0 per cent and not more than the equivalent of 102.0 per cent of 3-acetamido-2,4,6-triiodo-5-(N-methylacetamido) benzoic acid, calculated with reference to the dried substance.

CHARACTERS

A white or almost white, crystalline powder, very slightly soluble in water, slightly soluble in alcohol, practically insoluble in ether. It dissolves in solutions of alkali hydroxides and alkali carbonates.

IDENTIFICATION

Examine by infrared absorption spectrophotometry (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.24), comparingwith the spectrum obtained with metrizoic acid NRP.

TESTS

Appearance of solution Dissolve 0.20 g in a mixture of 5 ml of dilute sodium hydroxide solution R and 5 ml of water R. The solution is clear (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.1) and colourless (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., Method II, 2.2.2).

pH (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.3) Suspend 0.40 g in 20 ml of water R and boil for 1 min. Cool the suspension under stirring and filter. The pH of the filtrate is between 2.7 and 3.0.

Related substances Examine by liquid chromatography (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.29).

Test solution Dissolve 25.0 mg of the substance to be examined in a mixture of 0.05 ml of 1 M sodium hydroxide and 10 ml of water R and dilute to 100.0 ml with water R.

Reference solution (a) Dissolve 25.0 mg of metrizoic acid NRP in a mixture of 0.05 ml of 1 M sodium hydroxide and 10 ml of water R and dilute to 100.0 ml with water R.

Reference solution (b) Dissolve 25.0 mg of diatrizoic acid in a mixture of 0.05 ml of 1 M sodium hydroxide and 10 ml of water R and dilute to 100.0 ml with water R.

Reference solution (c) Dilute 1.0 ml of reference solution (b) to 100.0 ml with water R.

Reference solution (d) Dilute 1.0 ml of the test solution to 100.0 ml with water R. Dilute 3.0 ml of this solution to 10.0 ml with water R.

Reference solution (e) Mix 1 ml of reference solution (a) with 1 ml of reference solution (b).

The chromatographic procedure may be carried out using:

- a stainless steel column 25 cm long and 4.6 mm in internal diameter packed with octadecylsilyl silicagel for chromatography R (5-10 microm):

- as the mobile phase at a flow rate of 1.3 ml per minute a mixture of 30 volumes of methanol R and 70 volumes of a 0.01 M solution of tetrabutylammonium chloride adjusted to pH 6 to 7 by the addition of dilute ammonia R1:

- as the detector a spectrophotometer set at 240 nm:

- a loop injector.

Inject separately 10 microl of each solution and continue the chromatography for 4 times the retention time of the main peak. In the chromatogram obtained with the test solution the area of the peak corresponding to diatrizoic acid is not greater than that in the chromatogram obtained with reference solution (c) (1 per cent) and the area of any other peak apart from the principal peak, is not greater than that in the chromatogram obtained with reference solution (d) (0.3 per cent). The test is not valid unless in the chromatogram obtained with reference solution (e) the resolution between the two peaks is greater than 1.5.

Free aromatic amines Protect the solutions from bright light . Dissolve 50 mg in 1.0 ml of 0.1 M sodium hydroxide, add 1.0 ml of a 2.5 g/l solution of sodium nitrite R and 1.0 ml of 5 M hydrochloric acid: let stand for 4 min, then shake vigorously for 10 s. After 1 min add 1.0 ml of a 25 g/l solution of ammonium sulphamate R. After 2 min add 7.0 ml of water R, filter and add 1.0 ml of a 10 g/l solution of naphtylethylenediamine dihydrochloride R. Measure the absorbance at 500 nm after 2 min: the absorbance is not greater than 0.02.

Inorganic iodide Not more than 20 ppm. Dissolve 2.50 g in 5 ml of 1 M sodium hydroxide and dilute to 10 ml with water R. Add dropwise dilute nitric acid R until the precipitation is complete, then add 3 ml of dilute nitric acid R. Filter and wash the precipitate with 5 ml of water R. Collect the filtrate and washings. Add 1 ml of dilute hydrogen peroxide solution R and 1 ml of methylene chloride R and shake. The lower layer is not more intensely coloured than a reference solution prepared simultaneously and in the same manner using a mixture of 5 ml of iodide standard solution (10 ppm I), 3 ml of dilute nitric acid R and 15 ml of water R.

Methanol Examine by gas chromatography (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.28).

Test solution Dissolve 1.0 g of the substance to be examined in a mixture of 0.5 ml of 5 M sodium hydroxide and 2 ml of water R, and adjust the pH to 7.0 to 7.5 by the addition of 1 M hydrochloric acid: dilute with water R to 5.0 ml.

Reference solution Dilute 2.0 g of methanol R to 100.0 ml with water R: dilute 1.0 ml of the resulting solution to 1000.0 ml with water R.

The chromatographic procedure may be carried out using:

- a glass column 2 m long and 2 mm in internal diameter, packed with porous polymer beads (e.g. Porapak Q 150-180 mesh).

- nitrogen for chromatography R as carrier gas at a flow rate of 25 ml per min.

- a flame-ionisation detector.

Maintain the temperature of the column at 50 graderC, that of the injection port at 150 graderC and that of the detector at 150 graderC. Inject 5 microl of each solution.

In the chromatogram obtained with the test solution the peak area due to methanol is not greater than the peak area due to methanol in the chromatogram obtained with the reference solution.

Heavy metals (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.4.8) 1.0 g complies with limit test C for heavy metals (20 ppm). Prepare the standard using 2 ml of lead standard solution (10 ppm Pb) R.

Loss on drying (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.32). Not more than 0.5 per cent, determined on 1.000 g by drying in an oven at 100 graderC to 105 graderC.

Sulphated ash (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.4.14). Not more than 0.1 per cent, determined on 1.0 g.

ASSAY

To 0.150 g in a glass-stoppered 250 ml flask add 18 ml of dilute sodium hydroxide solution R, 12 ml of water R, 0.5 g of powdered zink R and a few glass beads. Boil under a reflux condenser for 30 min. Allow to cool and rinse the condenser with 20 ml of water R. Filter and wash the filter with several quantities of water R. Collect the filtrate and washings. Add 5 ml of glacial acetic acid R and titrate immediately with 0.1 M silver nitrate, determining the end-point potentiometrically, using a silver electrode as indicator electrode and a mercurous sulphate electrode as comparison electrode (Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed., 2.2.20).

1 ml of 0.1 M silver nitrate is equivalent to 20.93 mg of C12H11I3N2O4.

STORAGE

Store protected from light.

REAGENTS

Diatrizoic acid C11H9I3N2O4(Mr614).3,5-Diacetamido-2,4,6-triiodo-benzoic acid.

White crystals, hygroscopic, very slightly soluble in water, slightly soluble in ethanol, practically insoluble in ether.

1 cm reference to the anhydrous substance.

PLASMA FOR FRACTIONATION, HUMAN

Plasma til fraktionering, humant

Plasma humanum ad seperationem

Plasma til fraktionering skal opfylde de i Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed. angivne kvalitetskrav i monografien »Human plasma for fractionation« og de anførte donortests skal udføres i overensstemmelse med de af Sundhedsstyrelsen fastsatte regler for undersøgelse af donorblod for syfilis, hepatitis B overfladeantigen, HIV antistoffer (type 1 og type 2), HTLV antistoffer (type I/II) og hepatitis C antistof.

WATER, STERILISED

Vand, sterilt

Aqua sterilisata

Vand, sterilt, skal opfylde de angivne krav for Sterilised water for injections i monografien Water for injections i Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed. SEKTION 3

FREMSTILLING AF LÆGEMIDLER

Produktion, kontrol og lagerhold af lægemidler skal finde sted i overensstemmelse med de regler, der er angivet i nærværende kapitel, samt de regler, der måtte være anført i de tilhørende lægemiddelformstandarder.

PRODUKTION

Råvarer

Råvarekvalitet

Når det af en monografi for en råvare i den Europæiske Farmakope eller i DLS fremgår, at der stilles specielle krav til renhed ved anvendelse til bestemte lægemiddelformer, skal en sådan råvare anvendes til fremstilling af lægemidler tilhørende disse.

Lægemiddelstof

Det skal ved fremstilling af et lægemiddel tilstræbes, at det får et indhold af lægemiddelstof, der er i overensstemmelse med lægemidlets deklaration. Såfremt lægemiddelstoffet består af en råvare, hvor det kvantitative indhold kan variere betydeligt, skal der ved fremstillingen tages højde for resultatet, der er opnået ved den kvantitative bestemmelse af den aktuelt anvendte batch af råvaren.

Hjælpestoffer

Vand til fortynding af hæmodialysekoncentrater

Til fortynding af hæmodialysekoncentrater skal anvendes vand af tilfredsstillende kvalitet. Det anbefales at bruge en kvalitet svarende til monografien »Haemodialysis solutions, concentrated, water for diluting«, Ph. Eur. 3rd Ed.

Farvestoffer

Lægemidler må, jvf. EF-direktiv 94/36/EC farves med de farvestoffer, der er optaget i nedenstående fortegnelse over godkendte farvestoffer.

Farvestofferne riboflavin, aktivt kul, calciumcarbonat og titandioxid skal opfylde de kvalitetskrav, der fremgår af de i DLS bekendtgjorte råvarestandarder. De øvrige farvestoffer skal opfylde de krav til identitet og renhed, der fremgår af den gældende fortegnelse over godkendte tilsætningsstoffer til levnedsmidler (Positivlisten), Levnedsmiddelstyrelsen.
